head.title: Webmaster Defends Bridge Data on Site

hedline.hl1: Webmaster Defends Bridge Data on Site

abstract.p: Steve Anderson letter on June 25 article disputes statements made about his Web site's position on once-proposed Oyster Bay-Rye bridge; holds he continues to support project (S)

block.p: The June 25 article ''If You Bought the Brooklyn Bridge, Here's Another One for Sale'' mentioned my Web site, www.NYCroads.com.

Since 1996, the site has provided information on expressways, parkways, bridges and tunnels -- built and unbuilt. News media have commented favorably. Like any work in progress, the site is continuously checked for errors, using multiple sources (including correspondence from transportation officials and professionals).
The June 25 article ''If You Bought the Brooklyn Bridge, Here's Another One for Sale'' mentioned my Web site, www.NYCroads.com.

Since 1996, the site has provided information on expressways, parkways, bridges and tunnels -- built and unbuilt. News media have commented favorably. Like any work in progress, the site is continuously checked for errors, using multiple sources (including correspondence from transportation officials and professionals).
The article said I ''toned down some of the language on the site'' concerning the once-proposed Oyster Bay-Rye bridge. This is not true.

Early in the Long Island Transportation 2000 study, sponsored by the Department of Transportation, the agency solicited recommendations, including cross-Sound bridges (Oyster Bay-Rye, Shoreham-New Haven). When notified about the story, I checked www.LITP2000.com and saw that only the Shoreham bridge was actually considered; the Oyster Bay location had been dropped.

While I updated my site to reflect this (as of this writing, the D.O.T. has dropped all Sound bridges from consideration), my support for the Oyster Bay-Rye bridge remains unwavering. Indeed, my pro-bridge position is shared by 63 percent of Long Islanders, according to a Newsday-News 12 Long Island survey in February.
